The facility is identified as not being in GOADS in 2008, however, the total emissions from the facility is greater than 25,000 metric tons CO2e. §98.233(s)(4) states that “for either first or subsequent year reporting, offshore facilities either within or outside of BOEMRE jurisdiction that were not covered in the previous BOEMRE data collection cycle shall use the most recent BOEMRE data collection and emissions estimation methods published by BOEMRE referenced in 30 CFR 250.302 through 304 to calculate and report emissions (GOADS) to report emissions”.  Also, 98.2(a)(2) (as referenced in 98.231(a)) states that “a facility that contains any source category that is listed in Table A-4 of this subpart that emits 25,000 metric tons CO2e or more per year in combined emissions from stationary fuel combustion units, miscellaneous uses of carbonate, and all applicable source categories that are listed in Tables A-3 and Table A-4 of this subpart.”  Therefore, based on the information provided, this facility is required to report equipment leaks, vented emissions and flare emissions under subpart W and stationary combustion emissions under subpart C for calendar year 2011.

question: Can we use 2011 BOEMRE data, rather than the previously available data from 2008, for reporting RY2011 emissions from an offshore petroleum and natural gas production facility?
answer: Yes, you can use the 2011 BOEMRE data for reporting RY2011 emissions from an offshore petroleum and natural gas production facility. The data collection and emissions estimation study conducted by BOEMRE in compliance with 30 CFR 250.302 through 304 provides the relevant information needed for reporting emissions from offshore production facilities. The 2011 BOEMRE data provides default emission factors for various components and equipment used in onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities, including leaking and non-leaking components, population emission factors, and average component counts for major equipment. Therefore, the 2011 BOEMRE data can be used for reporting RY2011 emissions from an offshore petroleum and natural gas production facility, as it provides comprehensive information for estimating emissions.

truth: BOEMRE typically publishes a GOADS study after March 31 of the year following the data collection.  Therefore, for Subpart W, offshore reporters subject to BOEMRE must use the latest BOEMRE published emissions data (which may be 2008, as the 2011 GOADS report may not be available).  As a further clarification, the reporters will report under Subpart W using the BOEMRE methodologies published in 30 CFR 250.302 through 304 with the latest BOEMRE emissions data.  In subsequent years, reporters in state and non-Gulf of Mexico waters will report using the GOADS methodologies published in 30 CFR 250.302 through 304, which historically have been published along with the GOADS emissions data.

question: If an offshore oil and gas production platform or facility is farther out in the ocean than the limit of state waters, as defined by the Submerged Lands Act, does that facility have to report emissions data to EPA for Subpart C?
answer: Offshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities must report emissions from all applicable stationary combustion sources following the requirements of 40 CFR 98 subpart C (General Stationary Fuel Combustion Sources). If an offshore oil and gas production platform or facility is farther out in the ocean than the limit of state waters, as defined by the Submerged Lands Act, then it is not considered to be within the scope of onshore petroleum and natural gas production or gathering and boosting facilities. Therefore, such a facility would not be required to report emissions data to EPA for Subpart W as the tables provided are specifically for onshore facilities. The formula analysis provided does not seem to be directly related to the question about offshore oil and gas production platform emissions reporting to the EPA for Subpart C.

truth: Please note that amendments were made in November 2010 (75 FR 74487) to extend applicability of the GHG Reporting Program to facilities “attached to or under the Outer Continental Shelf.”  Those same rule amendments amended the definition of United States.  (See p. 74488 in http://edocket.access.gpo.gov/2010/pdf/2010-28655.pdf.)

question: By when do onshore and offshore production facilities subject to CFR 98 Subpart W need to report?
answer: Onshore and offshore production facilities subject to CFR 98 Subpart W need to report in accordance with the requirements outlined in the subpart. The reporting includes various aspects such as emissions from fuel combusted in stationary or portable equipment, venting, gathering and boosting operations, and recordkeeping requirements. Additionally, the reporting deadline is specified in the regulation, and users should refer to the specific sections of CFR 98 Subpart W for detailed reporting requirements and deadlines. The provided tables contain default emission factors for various components and equipment used in onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, and other related activities, which can be used to estimate emissions from the equipment. Therefore, onshore and offshore production facilities subject to CFR 98 Subpart W are required to report by the deadline specified in the regulation and comply with the specific reporting requirements outlined in the subpart.

truth: For an onshore producton facility, if the facility is subject to Subpart W in 2011, then the facility must report all combustion emissions, equipment leaks, flared emissions, and vented emissions as required under subpart W for 2011 by September 28, 2012.  For offshore production platforms, if the facility is subject to both subparts W and C in 2011, then the facility must report all combustion emissions under subpart C and all equipment leaks, flared, and vented emissions as required under subpart W for 2011 from by September 28, 2012.  If the facility submitted a report under subpart C for 2010, it is required to notify the EPA through e-GGRT by March 31, 2012 that they are not required to submit their second annual GHG report until September 28, 2012.  Any facility, as defined in 98.6, with annual stationary fuel combustion emissions greater than or equal to 25,000 metric tons CO2e in 2010 was required to report combustion emissions under subpart C by September 30, 2011.

question: Is it necessary to monitor of "hours operated" for "natural gas, diesel, and dual-fired turbines" as required in Subpart W via GOADS.
answer: Yes, it is necessary to monitor the 'hours operated' for 'natural gas, diesel, and dual-fired turbines' as required in Subpart W via GOADS. This is important for compliance with the regulations and accurate reporting of emissions from the combustion of natural gas, diesel, and dual-fired turbines. The table information provided includes default emission factors for various equipment and components in different natural gas facilities, but the specific requirement to monitor 'hours operated' for the mentioned turbines is not directly addressed. Therefore, it is recommended to refer to the specific regulatory requirements in Subpart W and GOADS to determine the necessity of monitoring 'hours operated' for the mentioned turbines. Additionally, monitoring the 'hours operated' for these turbines is crucial for accurately tracking and reporting emissions, calculating annual total emissions, and ensuring compliance with the regulations.

truth: You must follow the methods in the rule. In response to industry comments regarding burden, EPA finalized requirements to use Bureau of Ocean Management (BOEM) GOADS reporting methods for all offshore facilities under Subpart W. As GOADS is under BOEM jurisdiction, EPA has no authority regarding GOADS guidelines or methods.

question: How are new offshore facilities that are subject to GOADS supposed to report in 2012? Since published GOADS data are not available, should they be using the GOADS methodologies to calculate the emissions?
answer: New offshore facilities subject to GOADS are required to report their emissions using the methodologies specified in the relevant tables provided in Subpart W of Part 98. Since published GOADS data are not available, the facilities should use the default emission factors and population emission factors provided in the tables to calculate their emissions. Additionally, the GHG emissions data for petroleum and natural gas emissions sources must be quality assured as applicable as specified in the regulations. Offshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities are calculated using Calculation Method 3 of § 98.233(j). Onshore gathering and boosting facilities have specific reporting requirements, and onshore natural gas processing facilities report the indication per facility, not per component type. Facilities in onshore petroleum and natural gas production, onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting have their own reporting specifications. It's important for facilities to refer to the specific tables relevant to their equipment and services to calculate their emissions in accordance with the requirements of Subpart W of Part 98. If there are any disputes regarding the results obtained by an alternative method for the purposes of determining fluorinated GHG for the GHG emissions calculations, the devices shall also be calibrated prior to a specified date.

truth: Therefore, if the facility is subject to the rule and is under BOEMRE jurisdiction but is a new facility that is not included in the most recently published GOADs report, then you must calculate calendar year 2011 emissions for equipment leaks, vent, and flare emission sources using the GOADS methodologies in the most recently published GOADS report. New facilities, whether or not under GOADS jurisdiction, have to follow 98.233(s)(4), which states, “For either first or subsequent year reporting, offshore facilities either within or outside of BOEMRE jurisdiction that were not covered in the previous BOEMRE data collection cycle shall use the most recent BOEMRE data collection and emissions estimation methods published by BOEMRE referenced in 30 CFR 250.302 through 304 to calculate and report emissions (GOADS) to report emissions.”

question: Are the emissions factors listed in Table W-1A for both leaking components and non-leaking components? How do you calculate emissions from leaking components if onshore petroleum and natural gas source are not required to monitor components?
answer: The emissions factors listed in Table W-1A are used to calculate equipment leak emissions for onshore petroleum and natural gas sources. The table provides default whole gas leaker emission factors for different equipment components and survey methods. These factors can be used to estimate emissions from leaking components in onshore petroleum and natural gas production and gathering facilities. If components are not required to be monitored, the default whole gas population emission factors listed in Table W-1A are used for the calculation of equipment leak emissions.

truth: Equipment leak emissions in onshore production are to be estimated using methods provided in 98.233(r)(2).  Hence, no leak detection of emissions is required for onshore production.  Table W-1A provides population emission factors, which represent the emissions on an average from the entire population of components – both leaking and non-leaking; please see section 6(d) of the Technical Support Document (http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_TSD.pdf) for further details on the concept of population emission factors.

It also explains that default whole gas population emission factors listed in Table W-1A are used for the calculation of equipment leak emissions if components are not required to be monitored.

question: In 98.233(j)(1) is the average thoroughput of oil an annual or daily average?
answer: The average throughput of oil in 98.233(j)(1) is an annual average. This can be inferred from the text analysis, which states that the total annual oil/condensate throughput is reported on an annual basis, and from the table analysis, which indicates that the emission factors provided in the tables are in units of scf/hour/component, suggesting an annual average rather than a daily average. The formula analysis also confirms that the average throughput of oil is indeed an annual average.

question: How should the daily oil throughput for onshore production storage tanks be determined to compare with the threshold of 10 barrels a day in 98.233.j(1)?
answer: The daily oil throughput for onshore production storage tanks can be determined by calculating the total annual oil/condensate throughput that is sent to all atmospheric tanks in the basin, in barrels. If the average daily natural gas throughput is greater than or equal to 0.4 million standard cubic feet per day, the reporting of this data element for onshore production can be delayed. Additionally, the volume of oil produced during the first 30 days of production after completions of each newly drilled well can also be considered for determining the daily oil throughput. To determine the daily oil throughput for onshore production storage tanks and compare it with the threshold of 10 barrels a day in 98.233(j)(1), you would need to calculate the total oil throughput for the day by summing the oil throughput from each storage tank using the formula: Total Oil Throughput = (Oil throughput from Storage Tank 1) + (Oil throughput from Storage Tank 2) + ... + (Oil throughput from Storage Tank n). Once you have the total oil throughput for the day, you can compare it with the threshold of 10 barrels a day as specified in 98.233(j)(1) to determine compliance. The steps to follow are: 1) Calculate the total oil throughput for the storage tanks over a year. 2) Divide the annual total oil throughput by 365 to obtain the daily oil throughput. 3) Compare the daily oil throughput with the threshold of 10 barrels a day as specified in 98.233(j)(1).

truth: It is EPA’s intent that the 10 barrels per day of oil throughput referenced in 98.233(j) be based on annual average daily throughput.  On an annual basis, the owner/operator must evaluate whether individual well pad produced hydrocarbon liquids falls above or below the equipment threshold and use monitoring methods appropriately.  For less than 10 barrels per day of oil throughput on an annual average daily basis, the reporter must determine if 98.233(j)(5) applies.

question: Which calculation from 98.233(o) should be used for centrifugal compressor venting at onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities?
answer: The method for calculating volumetric GHG emissions from centrifugal compressor venting at onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities is specified in § 98.233(o)(4) and (5). This section provides the guidelines for as found measurements of manifolded emissions from groups of centrifugal compressor sources, which are essential for calculating the emissions accurately. Additionally, the calculation from Table W–1E to Subpart W of Part 98 should be used for centrifugal compressor venting at onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities. The table provides the default whole gas leaker emission factors for onshore petroleum and natural gas production and gathering facilities, categorized based on the survey methods specified in § 98.234(a)(1) through (7). It's important to consult the relevant regulations, industry standards, or engineering guidelines to determine the appropriate calculation for centrifugal compressor venting in this context.

answer: The EPA does not have the hydrocarbon basin map referenced in 98.238 available on their website. question: For combustion equipment that triggered Subpart C reporting, can this be incorporated into Subpart W reporting for CY2011, or will there be 2 separate (Subpart C and Subpart W) reporting schema?
answer: The emissions from stationary fuel combustion units must be reported under subpart C of this part, including reporting the emissions of CO2, CH4, and N2O from each stationary combustion unit. Therefore, the reporting for combustion equipment that triggered Subpart C reporting should be incorporated into Subpart W reporting for CY2011, as there will not be two separate reporting schemas. Additionally, the default whole gas and leaker emission factors for various processes are provided in tables W-1A, W-1E, W-2, W-3A, W-3B, W-4A, W-4B, W-5A, and W-5B for onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, processing, transmission compression, and underground storage, as well as LNG storage. This information can be used in the reporting process for Subpart W.

truth: Onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities and natural gas distribution facilities must report stationary and portable combustion emissions as specified in §98.233(z).  For all other source categories in Subpart W, emissions from each stationary fuel combustion unit must be reported under subpart C.

question: For an onshore natural gas production facility for which I reported stationary combustion emissions under subpart C for RY2010 and for which I will be reporting under subpart W for RY2011, do I need to make any changes to my RY2010 report?
answer: Yes, you need to make changes to your RY2010 report for the onshore natural gas production facility. The reporting requirements under subpart W for RY2011 include additional details such as the calculation method used, GHG mole fraction in produced natural gas, and the quantity of certain emissions. Therefore, adjustments to the RY2010 report are necessary to comply with the updated reporting specifications for RY2011. This may involve using the default whole gas emission factors, average component counts, leaker emission factors, population emission factors, and methane emission factors provided in the relevant tables for RY2011 reporting under subpart W. It is important to note that the reporting requirements for RY2010 under subpart C and RY2011 under subpart W are separate, and there are no retroactive changes needed for the RY2010 report.

question: For an onshore natural gas production facility that was subject to subpart C for RY2010 and will be subject to subpart W for RY2011, do I report my basin emissions under the same facility registration I used for my RY2010 report?
answer: Yes, you should report your basin emissions under the same facility registration used for your RY2010 report. This is based on the requirement that a person or entity who owns or operates more than one well in a basin should consider all onshore petroleum and natural gas production equipment associated with all wells as one facility. Additionally, for an onshore natural gas production facility that was subject to subpart C for RY2010 and will be subject to subpart W for RY2011, you will need to report your basin emissions under the same facility registration used for the RY2010 report. The emission factors and component counts provided in the tables will help in estimating the emissions for the RY2011 report under subpart W.

question: Are the results of Equations W-11A and W-11B in standard conditions or actual conditions?
answer: The results of Equations W-11A and W-11B are in standard conditions. The standard temperature and pressure (STP) for the purposes of this part means either 60 or 68 degrees Fahrenheit and at an absolute pressure of 1 atmosphere. This is supported by the formula analysis, which indicates that Equations W-11A and W-11B provide the calculation for annual total volumetric GHG emissions at standard conditions in standard cubic feet per year. Additionally, the table analysis confirms that the emission factors listed in various tables are for actual conditions, providing further context to the standard conditions specified for Equations W-11A and W-11B.

question: Why did EPA require that facilities conducting onshore petroleum and natural gas production report by basin?
answer: The EPA requires that facilities conducting onshore petroleum and natural gas production report by basin in order to accurately capture and analyze the emissions data specific to each geologic province. This approach allows for a more detailed and comprehensive understanding of the environmental impact and greenhouse gas emissions associated with petroleum and natural gas production in different geological regions. By reporting emissions data by basin, the EPA can better assess the environmental implications and develop targeted regulatory measures to mitigate the impact of onshore petroleum and natural gas production on a regional basis. Additionally, reporting by basin helps capture the variability in emission factors and population emission factors across different geographical areas, leading to more accurate estimation of emissions. Furthermore, this approach facilitates the tracking and monitoring of CO2e emissions, calibration errors, reference values, and destruction efficiency associated with the annual CO2 mass emissions for specific fuel types in metric tons, enabling more effective environmental management and policy implementation.

truth: When the GHGRP requirements for onshore petroleum and natural gas production were proposed, EPA’s goal was to provide a facility definition that all producers could directly apply, and that would be both practical and cost-effective.  EPA sought public comment on a range of possible options for defining the facility that would report with respect to onshore petroleum and natural gas production, ranging from defining the facility at the individual well pad, to defining the facility at the field-level, to defining the facility at the basin-level.  Taking into account public comment, EPA finalized the definition of facility with respect to onshore petroleum and natural gas production using a basin-level approach because the operational boundaries and basin demarcations are clearly defined and are widely known, and the approach covered most emissions from onshore petroleum and natural gas production.

question: If a facility does not have a GOR value for a well, what options are available to facilities in order to determine GOR for associated gas venting and flaring?
answer: Facilities without a GOR value for a well have several options to determine GOR for associated gas venting and flaring. They can conduct a well test to measure the volume of gas produced along with the volume of oil using a separator. Alternatively, they can estimate the GOR based on historical data from similar wells in the region or by using empirical correlations based on reservoir and fluid properties. Additionally, the rule allows using the GOR from a cluster of wells in the associated sub-basin category if individual well GOR values are not available, ensuring that the GOR for associated natural gas venting and flaring can still be determined.

truth: Facilities have several options to determine GOR for associated gas venting and flaring.  If the GOR from each well is not available, EPA has provided flexibility in 40 CFR 98.233(m) and the GOR from a cluster of wells in the same sub-basin category shall be used. If GOR is still not available, then an appropriate standard method published by a consensus-based standards organization or industry standard practice (as described in 40 CFR 98.234(b)) may be used.

question: What are the optional delayed reporting requirements for wildcat wells and delineation wells?
answer: The optional delayed reporting requirements for wildcat wells and delineation wells are specified in § 98.236(cc) of the relevant regulatory documents. If you elect to delay reporting of the data element related to wildcat wells and delineation wells, you must report by the date specified in § 98.236(cc) the measured average annual production for each sub-basin and well type combination. Additionally, you may delay reporting of this data element if you indicate in the annual report that wildcat wells and/or delineation wells are the only wells that can be used for the measurement. The table analysis did not provide specific information on optional delayed reporting requirements for wildcat wells and delineation wells, as it mainly contained default emission factors for various components and equipment in different services. question: How do I determine the gas to oil ratio (GOR) for my oil well operations to decide whether I need to report emissions from completions and workovers of oil wells with hydraulic fracturing?
answer: To determine the gas to oil ratio (GOR) for oil well operations, you can calculate the ratio of the volume of gas at standard temperature and pressure produced from a volume of oil using the formula GOR = Gas Production Rate / Oil Production Rate. This will give you the ratio of the volume of gas produced to the volume of oil produced. If the GOR is 300 scf/STB or greater for completions with hydraulic fracturing, it must be reported. The GOR can be determined by measuring the gas flowback rate during well completions and workovers and comparing it to the 30-day gas production rate. If GOR from each well is not available, the GOR from a cluster of wells can be used to calculate the average GOR of all wells. Additionally, the average API gravity of all wells and the average flow rate for well(s) tested in barrels of oil per day must be reported. You can also use the information provided in the tables W-1A, W-1B, W-1C, W-1D, W-1E, W-2, W-3A, W-3B, W-4A, W-4B, W-5A, W-5B, W-6A, W-6B, and W-7 of Subpart W of Part 98, which contain default emission factors and component counts for various equipment and facilities involved in onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, processing, transmission, storage, LNG operations, and distribution. By using the emission factors and component counts relevant to your specific operations, you can calculate the GOR and determine whether you need to report emissions from completions and workovers of oil wells with hydraulic fracturing. It's important to consult the relevant environmental regulatory authorities to determine the reporting obligations based on the GOR and other operational factors.

question: How should a gathering and boosting facility that previously reporting under Subpart C report in RY2016?
answer: In RY2016, the gathering and boosting facility that previously reported under Subpart C should report CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from various source types using Equation W–29D of this section. They should also calculate CH4 and CO2 emissions using the GWPs in Table A–1 of subpart A of this part. Additionally, the facility should use the default whole gas emission factors provided in Table W-1A for onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting facilities to estimate their methane emissions for reporting in RY2016. Furthermore, the facility is required to report the cumulative hours of venting, days, or times of operation in § 98.233(e), (g), (o), (p), and (exported). If there are specific calculations or concepts needed, further details should be provided for appropriate assistance.

truth: Gathering and boosting segment facilities that previously reported their stationary combustion emissions under Subpart C for RY2015 and previous years must report their stationary combustion emissions under Subpart W beginning in RY2016 (reports due March 31, 2017) and going forward.Beginning in 2016, facilities that meet the definition of the new Onshore Petroleum and Natural Gas Gathering and Boosting segment (aka “gathering and boosting”) in Subpart W will report emissions for all the source categories listed in 40 CFR 98.232(j).  This includes stationary and portable fuel combustion equipment emissions that may have previously been reported under Subpart C.

question: How do I determine the gas to oil ratio (GOR) for my gathering pipelines?
answer: To determine the gas to oil ratio (GOR) for gathering pipelines, there are several approaches you can take. Firstly, you can use the GOR from each well in the production gas/oil ratio and API gravity. If GOR from each well is not available, you can use the GOR from a cluster of wells. Additionally, you can use the default whole gas emission factors provided in Table W-1A to Subpart W of Part 98 to calculate the GOR by comparing the emission factors for gas service components with the emission factors for heavy crude service components. Furthermore, you would need to know the volume of gas and oil being produced or transported through the gathering pipelines in order to calculate the GOR by dividing the volume of gas by the volume of oil. Gathering pipelines with a GOR less than 300 standard cubic feet per stock tank barrel (scf/STB) are not included in this industry segment. Therefore, the GOR for gathering pipelines can be determined based on the GOR from individual wells or a cluster of wells, considering the specific requirements for GOR in the given context.

truth: The gathering and boosting system owner or operator can use a direct measurement of GOR through either onsite measurement or by sending samples out for laboratory analysis. The timing and duration of the sampling/measurement program should follow existing regulatory requirements, which include standard methods published by a consensus-based standards organization or industry standard practices. See 40 CFR 98.234(b). The EPA realizes that owners or operators may calculate GOR for other reasons such as documenting fluid quality for financial transactions, equipment optimization or other state/federal reporting requirements. These values can be used where appropriate.A825. 40 CFR Part 98, Subpart W does not prescribe a specific approach to calculate GOR. Gathering and boosting system operators may use the best approach for their facility, including direct measurement, calculation from other measured data, and standard estimation measures. We note that within the EPA’s 2016 updates to New Source Performance Standards for the oil and natural gas sector, GOR is defined as the ratio of the volume of gas at standard temperature and pressure that is produced from a volume of oil when depressurized to a standard temperature and pressure. See 40 CFR 60.5430a.

question: My gathering pipeline is exempt based on Gas to Oil Ratio. Does the exemption only apply to the pipeline itself, or is all equipment along the pipeline excluded as well?
answer: The exemption based on Gas to Oil Ratio (GOR) applies to the entire gathering pipeline and all equipment along the pipeline. Therefore, all equipment along the gathering pipeline is excluded from the exemption. This conclusion is based on the text analysis result. However, the table analysis result suggests that the exemption only applies to the gathering pipeline itself and not to the equipment along the pipeline. The formula analysis result does not provide relevant details for the question. Therefore, there is a discrepancy between the text and table analysis results, and further clarification may be needed to determine the accurate scope of the exemption for the gathering pipeline and its equipment based on Gas to Oil Ratio.

question: Can facilities covered by the Subpart W Onshore Petroleum and Natural Gas Gathering and Boosting industry segment use Subpart C emission factors for calculating combustion emissions?
answer: Facilities covered by the Subpart W Onshore Petroleum and Natural Gas Gathering and Boosting industry segment cannot use Subpart C emission factors for calculating combustion emissions. The requirements of subpart C are not applicable for facilities under onshore petroleum and natural gas production, onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting, and natural gas processing. Instead, the emissions should be calculated using Calculation Method 3 of § 98.233(j) as specified for onshore gathering and boosting facilities. Additionally, specific information such as the number of atmospheric tanks, cumulative hours of venting, and other equipment/activities must be reported as per the guidelines outlined in the subpart W of this part. Furthermore, facilities should refer to the specific emission factors provided in the relevant tables such as Table W-1A, Table W-1E, Table W-3A, Table W-4A, Table W-5A, Table W-6A, and Table W-7 for different equipment components and services when calculating combustion emissions. It's important to ensure that the correct data related to the Subpart W Onshore Petroleum and Natural Gas Gathering and Boosting industry segment is being considered for the emission factor calculations.

truth: Combustion emissions for the Onshore Petroleum and Natural Gas Gathering and Boosting segment are calculated using methods outlined in 40 CFR 98.233(z). Those methods provide flexibility to use Subpart C emission factors if the fuel combusted is natural gas, is pipeline quality, and has a minimum high heat value of 950 Btu per standard cubic foot. If the fuel meets those criteria, then you may use the emission factor for natural gas as listed in 40 CFR Part 98, Subpart C, Table C-1.  See 40 CFR 98.233(z)(1).

question: Section 98.230(a)(3) states that processing plants "that do not fractionate but have an annual average throughput of 25 MMscf per day or greater" are included in the source category. Is this based on annual average daily flow or max design capacity?
answer: Based on the text analysis, the annual average throughput of 25 MMscf per day or greater is determined by the actual annual average flow, not the maximum design capacity. The table analysis provides information on emissions factors for leaking and non-leaking components in onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities, which is not directly related to the question. The formula analysis indicates that the provided information is not directly related to the question about Section 98.230(a)(3). Therefore, based on the text analysis, the determination of processing plants being included in the source category is based on the actual annual average flow, not the maximum design capacity.

question: What is the definition of  "fractionate" and "fractionation" in 98.230(a)(3)?
answer: In 98.230(a)(3), the term 'fractionate' refers to the process of separating a mixture of natural gas liquids (NGLs) into its individual constituents or components. This process is typically carried out by natural gas liquids fractionators, which are installations that fractionate NGLs into their constituent mixtures or blends. The fractionator follows specific procedures outlined in the regulations, including the use of equations for estimating CO2 emissions, reporting quantities of constituents separately, and complying with calculation methodologies for emissions estimation. Additionally, the fractionator may need to report information related to the volume of oil, mass of biomass combusted, and other operational parameters as specified in the subpart. The definition and procedures are essential for ensuring accurate reporting and monitoring of greenhouse gas emissions from fractionation processes. The provided tables contain default emission factors for various components and equipment used in onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, transmission, storage, LNG facilities, and natural gas distribution, but do not explicitly provide the definition of 'fractionate' and 'fractionation' in 98.230(a)(3). It's recommended to review the source document or context related to 98.230(a)(3) to find the specific definitions of 'fractionate' and 'fractionation'.

question: Under onshore natural gas processing where are vent emissions reported?
answer: Vent emissions from onshore natural gas processing are reported for CO2, CH4, and N2O. These emissions are reported for equipment such as natural gas compressors, electrical generators, steam boilers, and process heaters as specified in § 98.232(d)(1). The emission factors for reporting vent emissions are provided in Table W–2 to Subpart W of Part 98, categorized based on the method used for surveying. To report vent emissions, it is typically done to the relevant environmental regulatory agency, such as the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in the United States. Specific reporting requirements may vary based on location and regulations, so it's important to consult the appropriate regulatory authority for guidance on reporting vent emissions from onshore natural gas processing.

truth: If a membrane unit is used to remove CO2 from natural gas containing concentrations of hydrogen sulfide or carbon dioxide that exceed the concentrations specified for commercially saleable nature gas, then emissions must be calculated and reported as specified in §98.233 (d), as this process meets the definition of acid gas removal unit in §98.238.  Please see EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1298-18 in the Response To Comments (1719 - 1720) http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf for further details on the definitions of sweet and sour gas.

question: In 98.230(a)(3), is 25 mmscf per day the design capacity for a processing plant or the actual capacity?
answer: Based on the text analysis, the design capacity is the maximum amount of solid waste a landfill can accept, and there is no direct mention of processing plant capacity. The table analysis indicates that the design capacity for a processing plant is not explicitly mentioned in the provided tables. The formula analysis also states that the provided information does not contain the relevant details to determine whether 25 mmscf per day is the design capacity or the actual capacity for a processing plant in 98.230(a)(3). Therefore, based on the available information, it is not possible to definitively determine whether 25 mmscf per day is the design capacity or the actual capacity for a processing plant.

question: If a natural gas processing plant is co-located with an underground storage facility and they share compression, can they report as one combined facility?
answer: Based on the provided information, a natural gas processing plant and an underground storage facility can report as one combined facility if they share compression operations. This is because the natural gas processing plant and the underground storage facility are closely linked in their operations, and the shared compression activities can be considered as part of a unified facility for reporting purposes. The emission factors and population emission factors from the tables can be used to calculate the combined emissions from the shared compression equipment, ensuring that all relevant components and services are accounted for in the calculations. However, it is important to consider the specific reporting requirements and regulations that may vary based on the location and governing environmental agencies. It is advisable to consult with the relevant regulatory authorities or environmental consultants to ensure compliance with reporting standards and guidelines.

question: If fuel gas lines are not owned or operated by a gas processing facility, but are on the gas processing facility property, do the fuel gas lines need to be monitored for equipment leaks?
answer: Based on the provided information, if the fuel gas lines are on the gas processing facility property and do not have a flow meter installed at any point in the line supplying fuel gas or an upstream common pipe, and the fuel gas line contains only vapors from loading or unloading, waste or wastewater handling, and remediation activities, then the fuel gas lines do not need to be monitored for equipment leaks. However, it is important to note that if fuel gas lines are on the gas processing facility property but not owned or operated by the facility, they may still need to be monitored for equipment leaks. The emission factors and population emission factors provided in the tables are specific to different equipment components and services, and they can be used to estimate emissions from leaking components. The specific emission factors for different components and services can be used to calculate the emissions from leaking components using the appropriate survey methods as specified in the relevant sections of the regulations. Additionally, it is important to monitor fuel gas lines for equipment leaks, regardless of ownership, to ensure safety, prevent environmental impact, and comply with regulations. Regular monitoring and maintenance of fuel gas lines can help in early detection and mitigation of leaks, thereby reducing the risk of accidents and minimizing emissions.

truth: The definition of “natural gas” in the final rule revision (December 23, 2011) excludes the composition and heat value specification and simply states: “Natural gas means a naturally occurring mixture or process derivative of hydrocarbon and non-hydrocarbon gases found in geologic formations beneath the earth's surface, of which its constituents include, but are not limited to, methane, heavier hydrocarbons and carbon dioxide.  Natural gas may be field quality, pipeline quality, or process gas.”  Based upon the finalized definition of “natural gas”, a facility that processes an inlet gas stream which is field gas could be included in the Onshore Natural Gas Processing segment if the process otherwise meets the definition of Onshore Natural Gas Processing.

The answer correctly identifies and summarizes this information.

question: Are facilities designed solely to fractionate natural gas liquid streams (and do not receive a gaseous form of natural gas containing methane) subject to subpart W?
answer: Based on the text analysis, facilities designed solely to fractionate natural gas liquid streams (and do not receive a gaseous form of natural gas containing methane) are subject to subpart W. However, the table analysis and formula analysis indicate that these facilities are not subject to subpart W because they do not deal with gaseous natural gas containing methane. Therefore, the final conclusion is that facilities designed solely to fractionate natural gas liquid streams and do not receive gaseous natural gas containing methane are not subject to subpart W.

question: How should I calculate the reporting threshold for onshore natural gas processing plants that do not fractionate gas liquids?
answer: To calculate the reporting threshold for onshore natural gas processing plants that do not fractionate gas liquids but have an annual average throughput of 25 MMscf per day or greater, the facility should determine the actual throughput of natural gas. If the annual average throughput of natural gas is 25 MMscf per day or greater, then the facility meets the reporting threshold for onshore natural gas processing. Additionally, the default emission factors provided in Table W-2 to Subpart W of Part 98 can be used to estimate the emissions from various components such as valves, connectors, open-ended lines, pressure relief valves, and meters by multiplying the emission factor with the number of components of each type in the plant. It's important to ensure that the units are consistent when performing these calculations. Furthermore, the reporting threshold can also be calculated using the formula: Reporting Threshold = 25,000 metric tons of CO2 equivalent per year, based on the EPA's Greenhouse Gas Reporting Program (GHGRP) requirements for onshore natural gas processing plants that do not fractionate gas liquids.

truth: The Rule states in §98.230(a) that the onshore natural gas processing industry includes all plants that fractionate, as well as all plants that do not fractionate that have an annual average throughput of 25 MMscf per day or greater.  Only those non-fractionating facilities with an annual average throughput of less than 25 MMscf per day would not be subject to reporting under subpart W even if the reporting threshold is triggered in Subpart C.  The gas processing plant throughput threshold in 98.230(a)(3) is based on annual average throughput.

question: What is the basis for the 25 MMscfd threshold for gas processing facilities in 98.230(a)(3) and how often must a facility re-evaluate whether it falls below this threshold?
answer: The basis for the 25 MMscfd threshold for gas processing facilities in 98.230(a)(3) is to determine whether a facility is a major source of greenhouse gas emissions. Gas processing facilities that have the potential to emit 25 MMscfd or more of natural gas are considered major sources. This threshold is based on the emissions from various source types, including natural gas pneumatic device venting, storage vessels, equipment for liquefying natural gas, compressors, and more. Facilities must re-evaluate their emissions annually to determine if they fall below this threshold and are no longer classified as major sources.

truth: However, please note that if, in year 2, your throughput capacity is less than 25 MMscf per day, you are not required to calculate and report GHG emissions from gas processing in year 2.  You would still be required to report other covered emissions at your facility.  This is because gas processing would not be an applicable segment for year 2.  Nevertheless, your facility would still be required to report in year 2, even if facility-wide emissions are less than 25,000mt CO2e, and would continue to report until you meet the criteria in 98.2(i) for ceasing to report.  The gas processing plant throughput threshold in 98.230(a)(3) is based on annual average throughput.  This throughput is re-evaluated annually.  Once you are subject to the rule (e.g., your facility contains a source category listed in Table A-4), your facility must continue complying with all the requirements of this part, even if the facility does not meet the applicability requirements in a future year (i.e., 25,000 mtCO2e for petroleum and natural gas systems). The definition of the source category for petroleum and natural gas systems, under onshore natural gas processing, refers to a processing facility that does not fractionate and has a throughput of 25MMscf per day or greater.  Because a gas processing facility that is over 25 MMscf per day meets the definition of the source category for subpart W, any facility that becomes subject to the rule in whole or in part because of a natural gas processing facility, would have to continue reporting until it meets the conditions for cessation of reporting in 98.2(i).

question: Which takes precedence for determining the Subpart W applicability of a natural gas processing facility- the 25,000 MT CO2e threshold (under 98.2(a)(2)) or the 25 MMscf per day throughput (under 98.230(a)(3))?
answer: The determination of Subpart W applicability for a natural gas processing facility is based on the 25 MMscf per day throughput (under 98.230(a)(3)) according to the table analysis. This throughput threshold is specifically related to the facility. However, the text analysis suggests that the 25,000 MT CO2e threshold (under 98.2(a)(2)) takes precedence as it specifies the applicability based on the facility's emissions of greenhouse gases. Considering both analyses, it is important to note that the formula analysis also supports the precedence of the 25 MMscf per day throughput. Therefore, while there may be differing perspectives, the weight of the evidence suggests that the throughput threshold is the primary factor in determining the Subpart W applicability of a natural gas processing facility.

truth: Since the throughput of the facility was identified in the question as 30 MMscf per day throughput capacity, this exceeds the exclusion identified in the §98.230(a)(3) for processing facilities that do not fractionate.  Therefore, this facility falls under the onshore natural gas processing industry segment definition as defined in §98.230(a)(3) and these emissions would be included in the applicability determination for your facility.  (If the throughput were less than 25 MMscf this source would not have been considered in the applicability determination for the facility.)  However, based on the information provided, since the processing facility has less than 25,000 metric tons CO2e in combined emissions from stationary combustion, flaring, vented, and fugitive sources, the facility does not need to report under subpart W.  Both the 25,000 metric ton CO2e threshold (from §98.2(a)(2)) and the 25 MMscf per day annual average throughput (from §98.230(a)(3)) are considered when determining subpart W applicability for a natural gas processing facility.

question: May engineering calculations be used for flare gas composition in equations W-19 through W-21 if the flared stream is a combination of gases from before and after the demethanizer as well as hydrocarbon product?
answer: Engineering calculations may be used for flare gas composition in Equations W-19 through W-21 if the flared stream is a combination of gases from before and after the demethanizer as well as hydrocarbon product. The engineering calculations should be based on accurate and representative data to ensure the reliability and validity of the results. However, for a precise calculation of flare gas composition, a detailed analysis of the specific gas streams and their compositions before and after the demethanizer, as well as the hydrocarbon product, would be necessary. The provided tables contain default emission factors for various components and equipment in different services, which can be used to estimate emissions from specific components and equipment in different processes. It is important to consider both the engineering calculations and the specific gas stream compositions for accurate results.

question: Under subpart W, are we required to calculate potential GHG emissions from compressors at a natural gas processing facility that are only used for refrigeration and use 100% propane?
answer: Based on the EPA's Greenhouse Gas Reporting Program (GHGRP) Subpart W, if the compressors at a natural gas processing facility are only used for refrigeration and use 100% propane, then you are not required to calculate potential GHG emissions from these compressors. Subpart W specifically exempts refrigeration systems that use non-ODS refrigerants, such as propane, from the calculation of GHG emissions. Therefore, in this case, you are not obligated to calculate potential GHG emissions from the compressors used for refrigeration with 100% propane. The regulations specify that emissions from reciprocating compressor venting at an onshore petroleum and natural gas production facility or an onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting facility must be calculated, but the use of compressors for refrigeration purposes at a natural gas processing facility falls under the exemption for non-ODS refrigerants like propane.

truth: 98.232 (d) states that “for onshore natural gas processing, report CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from the following sources”.  For example, if the compressor stream is 100% propane then the emissions will not include CO2, CH4 and N2O emissions and therefore will not have to be reported under subpart W.  However, if the facility exceeds the 25,000 mtCO2e threshold then the owner or operator must report combustion emissions for this compressor under subpart C.

Subpart W specifically exempts refrigeration systems that use non-ODS refrigerants, such as propane, from the calculation of GHG emissions. question: Under Subpart W of Part 98, the definition of Natural Gas Processing provides an unclear explanation of fractionation, additionally, fractionation is not defined within the rule.
answer: Fractionation, as it pertains to Subpart W of Part 98, refers to the process of separating natural gas liquids (NGLs) into individual component products such as ethane, propane, normal butane, isobutane, or pentanes plus, for supply to downstream facilities. This process is typically carried out in natural gas processing plants. The emission factors provided in the tables are for various components and equipment used in onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, processing, transmission, storage, and distribution. The emission factors are used to estimate methane emissions from the various stages of natural gas production, processing, and distribution. However, the definition of fractionation is not explicitly provided in the rule, leading to potential confusion and inconsistency in reporting for natural gas processing facilities. It would be beneficial for the regulatory body to provide a clear and specific definition of fractionation within the rule to ensure accurate and consistent reporting by facilities.

question: What is the difference between the methods in 98.233(k) and 98.234(a)(1) for monitoring tank emissions?  How do we treat intermittent emission from the storage tank? Can we use an alternative method to quantify the emissions?
answer: The difference between the methods in 98.233(k) and 98.234(a)(1) for monitoring tank emissions is that 98.233(k) focuses on monitoring for venting residual fluorinated GHGs, while 98.234(a)(1) involves monitoring for emissions from equipment leaks. Additionally, 98.233(k) pertains to the monitoring of whole gas emissions from onshore petroleum and natural gas production and gathering facilities, while 98.234(a)(1) is specific to the survey methods for leaker emissions from various components in different services such as gas, light crude, and heavy crude services. Intermittent emissions from the storage tank can be treated by using a site-specific leak monitoring method or using the specific emission factors provided in the tables for different equipment components and services. An alternative method can be used to quantify the emissions if it meets the requirements specified in the regulations.

truth: The purpose of this detection and measurement is to determine and quantify any continuous gas emissions from condensate storage tanks.  The most common source of vapor emissions from a transmission compressor station condensate tank would be liquid transfer from compressor scrubber dump valves.  These sources operating properly would be intermittent transfer of liquids from high pressure vessels to an atmospheric storage tank, with a short term flashing of dissolved gas, which is assumed to be less than 5 minutes in duration.  Malfunction of scrubber dump valves can result in high pressure vapor leaking through the valve, into the condensate tank, and out the tank roof vent, which would vent indefinitely.  This continuous release of vapor is detected as a continuous blow of gas from the condensate tank roof vent using a leak imaging camera or by using an acoustic through-valve leak detection instrument.  Based on the current rule, when using an optical gas imaging instrument, the tank needs to be monitored to determine whether the tank vapors are continuous for 5 minutes; see section 98.233(k)(2).  So if a leak is detected per requirements of 98.234(a)(1) and is continuous per the requirements of 98.233(k)(2) then the reporter has to measure the emissions per requirements in 98.233(k)(2)(i)-(iv).  The reporter has the choice of using an acoustic leak detection device to detect and measure leaks per requirements in 98.234(a)(5).  You cannot use alternative methods to those outlined in the rule.

question: For transmission tank venting sent to the flare, the reporter is referred to the emissions source for flare stack emissions, but guidance is only provided for upstream production and gas processing in this section.
answer: For transmission tank venting sent to the flare, the specific guidance for flare stack emissions is not explicitly provided in the emissions source tables. However, the text analysis indicates that emissions from transmission storage tanks venting to a flare should be reported using the calculation method specified in the regulations. It also mentions that the calculation method for flare stacks should be used to determine storage tank emissions sent to a flare. Additionally, the text provides specific instructions for reporting emissions if dump valve leakage occurred for a transmission storage tank vent stack and it vented directly to the atmosphere. It also mentions the calculation of well testing venting and flaring, and the reporting of the volume of gas sent to the flare. Therefore, while the emissions factors for transmission tank venting sent to the flare are not explicitly provided in the tables, the specific reporting requirements and calculation methods are outlined in the text analysis, indicating that additional guidance or specific calculations may be required to determine the emission factors for transmission tank venting sent to the flare.

question: In the natural gas transmission segment, do only condensate tanks at the facilities require leak checks (not other tanks at the facility or not at the facility)?
answer: In the natural gas transmission segment, only condensate tanks at the facilities require leak checks, while other tanks at the facility do not require leak checks. This is based on the text analysis, table analysis, and formula analysis results, which all support the conclusion that leak checks are specifically required for condensate tanks at the facilities.

question: The definition of the onshore natural gas transmission compression includes "any stationary combustion of compressors that move natural gas at elevated pressure
answer: The definition of onshore natural gas transmission compression includes any stationary combination of compressors that move natural gas at elevated pressure. This process involves using stationary combustion engines to power compressors that transport natural gas at high pressure. The emission factors for onshore natural gas transmission compression are provided in Table W-3A to Subpart W of Part 98, specifying factors for different components and survey methods as specified in § 98.234(a)(1) through (7). The combustion of these engines is a key component of the onshore natural gas transmission compression process.

question: How does a natural gas compressor station that operates compressors for natural gas transmission and an emergency generator determine subpart applicability?
answer: The subpart requires reporting of CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from various sources such as reciprocating compressor venting, centrifugal compressor venting, transmission storage tanks, blowdown vent stacks, natural gas pneumatic device venting, flare stack emissions, and emergency generator operations. Therefore, a natural gas compressor station that operates compressors for natural gas transmission and an emergency generator must determine subpart applicability based on the emissions of CO2, CH4, and N2O from these sources as specified in the subpart. This determination can be made by referring to the specific emission factors and population emission factors provided in the relevant tables, as well as reviewing the definitions and criteria outlined in the applicable subpart of the Clean Air Act. Factors such as the type and capacity of the compressors, the quantity of natural gas transmitted, the type and usage of the emergency generator, and the location of the station should be carefully considered to accurately determine the subpart applicability for the given natural gas compressor station and emergency generator.

truth: For the purpose of determining the applicability of 40 CFR part 98 for the 2010 reporting year, the facility should calculate the emissions from the gas compressors pursuant to 40 CFR 98.30(a)(2). So long as a the emergency generators meet the definition of “emergency equipment” as stated in 98.6, emissions from the emergency generators are exempt and should not be calculated.  If the facility is subject to 40 CFR part 98, you should report combustion emissions pursuant to the applicable requirements of subpart C (General Stationary Fuel Combustion Sources).  Pursuant to 40 CFR 98.2, if a facility’s calculated total annual emissions are less than 25,000 metric tons of CO2e and the facility does not contain a source category listed in Table A-3 of 40 CFR part 98, subpart A, then the facility does not have to report under 40 CFR part 98 as a direct emitter.

question: Are CO2 pipelines subject to the Onshore natural gas transmission compression segment under 40 CFR 98 subpart W?
answer: Based on the provided information, CO2 pipelines are not subject to the Onshore natural gas transmission compression segment under 40 CFR 98 subpart W. The table analysis provided default emission factors for various components and equipment in different segments of the natural gas industry, but did not specifically address the applicability of the Onshore natural gas transmission compression segment to CO2 pipelines. The formula analysis did not provide relevant information related to CO2 pipelines and natural gas transmission. question: Are unintentional natural gas releases such as those resulting from accidental releases subject to reporting?
answer: Yes, unintentional natural gas releases such as those resulting from accidental releases are subject to reporting. The regulations require reporting of various emissions including those from equipment leaks, venting, and combustion, as well as specific types of emissions from different source types within the oil and natural gas system facilities. The emission factors provided in the tables give the emission rates for different components and equipment in various natural gas production and distribution facilities. These emission factors can be used to estimate the emissions from unintentional releases based on the component counts and the specific emission factors for each component type.

truth: Onshore natural gas transmission pipeline facilities must report emissions of carbon dioxide and methane from blowdown vent stacks to the GHGRP if facility-wide annual emissions are 25,000 metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalents (mtCO2e) or greater. This requirement applies to blowdown vent stack emissions from the depressurization of equipment for both planned and emergency shutdowns.

question: How do we report emissions from separate facilities that inject or withdraw gas from the same underground storage reservoir?
answer: Emissions from separate facilities that inject or withdraw gas from the same underground storage reservoir must be reported individually for each facility. This includes reporting the mass of CO2 emissions from equipment leaks and vented emissions of CO2 from surface equipment located on the surface between the flow meter used to measure injection quantity and the injection wellhead. Each facility must report its own emissions without combining them with emissions from other facilities. Additionally, the emissions can be reported by using the default whole gas leaker emission factors provided in Table W–4A to Subpart W of Part 98 for underground natural gas storage. These emission factors include values for various components such as valves, connectors, open-ended lines, pressure relief valves, meters, and other components. The emission factors can be used to estimate the methane emissions from the respective components at the facilities, and the total emissions can be calculated by summing the emissions from all relevant components at each facility.

truth: Underground storage and compression and transmission compression are two separate industry segments.  A “facility”, as defined in 40 CFR 98.6, must determine if it contains any of the industry segments listed in subpart W and compare its emissions from all applicable industry segments against the 25,000 mtCO2e threshold defined in 40 CFR 98.2(a)(2) to determine applicability.  For a response to the question related to multipurpose facilities and dual purpose equipment, please see the response to EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1024-14 (see pp. 1606-1608 in http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf).  If multiple owners or operators use the same underground storage operation, one designated representative must be appointed for reporting purposes.

question: Could EPA clarify that the natural gas stored in high pressure steel bottles at peak-shaving stations should NOT be considered an underground natural gas storage facility under Subpart W?
answer: Based on the information provided, the natural gas stored in high pressure steel bottles at peak-shaving stations should NOT be considered an underground natural gas storage facility under Subpart W of Part 98. The emission factors and population emission factors provided in the tables are specific to various components and equipment used in onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, transmission compression, LNG storage, and distribution. Since the specific storage of natural gas in high pressure steel bottles at peak-shaving stations falls outside the scope of the emission factors and population emission factors provided in these tables, it further supports the conclusion that it should not be considered an underground natural gas storage facility under Subpart W.

truth: High pressure steel bottles that store natural gas at peak-shaving stations without any subsurface storage per section 98.230(a)(5) would not be considered underground natural gas storage under Subpart W.  However, if the high pressure steel bottles are located at underground storage per section 98.230(a)(5) then the equipment leak sources listed in 98.232(f)(5) would be subject to reporting.

question: What is the definition of "facility" for underground storage?
answer: The definition of 'facility' for underground storage includes subsurface storage of natural gas, liquefied natural gas (LNG) storage, importers or exporters of bulk CO2, and underground natural gas storage facilities. It also encompasses equipment leaks, equipment surveys, and the use of CO2 in enhanced oil and gas recovery. The definition can be found in Table W–4A to Subpart W of Part 98, which provides default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for underground natural gas storage. The emission factors are specified for different components such as valves, connectors, open-ended lines, pressure relief valves, meters, and other components, and are used to estimate the emissions from underground natural gas storage facilities. The formula analysis did not directly address the definition of 'facility' for underground storage, as it focused on mathematical expressions, conversion factors, and equations related to emissions, mass, volume, and other parameters.

truth: A “facility”, as defined in 40 CFR 98.6, must determine if it contains any of the industry segments listed in subpart W and compare its emissions against the 25,000 mtCO2e threshold defined in 40 CFR 98.2(a)(2) to determine applicability.  Underground natural gas storage is as defined in §98.230(a)(5) and includes reporting of GHGs as listed in §98.232(f)(1) through (5).  Therefore, the reporter needs to determine all applicable sources as per this industry segment definition and sources to report.  Specifically, filters and separators are not listed as sources under 98.232(f)(1) through (5) but if filters or separators are associated with any sources under this section, reporting of those listed sources is still required.  The sources required to report under the underground storage source category are listedin §98.232(f).  In this list dehydration units are not included therefore reporting from this source type is not required.

question: If a company owns and operates an underground storage facility but the associated storage wellheads are owned jointly with a second company but operated by the second company, should the respective operators to submit separate emission reports?
answer: Based on the provided information, if a company owns and operates an underground storage facility but the associated storage wellheads are owned jointly with a second company but operated by the second company, the respective operators should submit separate emission reports. This is because the ownership and operational responsibilities are divided between the two companies, and each operator is responsible for reporting the emissions associated with their respective ownership and operational activities. The emission factors and population emission factors provided in the tables further support this, as they are specific to different equipment components, services, and regions. Therefore, each company should separately report the emissions associated with the equipment they own and operate, as well as the jointly owned equipment that is operated by the second company. The formula analysis did not directly address the specific question about separate emission reports for companies jointly owning and operating an underground storage facility with associated storage wellheads, so it does not provide additional insight into this particular scenario.

question: Why do natural gas storage facilities not have different emission factors for compressor and non-compressor components like those for the natural gas transmission segment.
answer: The emission factors for natural gas storage facilities do not have different values for compressor and non-compressor components like those for the natural gas transmission segment. The emission factors for natural gas storage facilities are based on the total hydrocarbon population and methane leaker emission factors, and they do not differentiate between compressor and non-compressor components. Additionally, the emission factors provided for natural gas storage facilities are based on the type of equipment and the service they provide, rather than being categorized based on compressor and non-compressor components. The emission factors are specific to the type of component and the type of service it is involved in, eliminating the need for separate emission factors for compressor and non-compressor components.

question: Does Subpart W require reporting of emissions during the salt dome mining process to create an underground natural gas storage facility or does reporting start only when natural gas is introduced for load balancing or storage?
answer: The reporting of emissions under Subpart W begins when natural gas is transferred from its original location for the primary purpose of load balancing or storage. This includes emissions from underground natural gas storage processes and operations, as well as all the wellheads connected to the compression units located at the facility. Additionally, Subpart W of Part 98 provides default emission factors for various components and equipment used in onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, transmission, storage, and distribution. However, the specific reporting requirements for emissions during the salt dome mining process to create an underground natural gas storage facility are not explicitly mentioned in the provided tables. It is recommended to refer to the specific regulatory requirements and consult with the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) for detailed guidance on reporting emissions during the salt dome mining process for underground natural gas storage facilities. Furthermore, the formula analysis indicates that the reporting of emissions under Subpart W is required during the salt dome mining process to create an underground natural gas storage facility, including reporting of emissions from the mining process itself, not just when natural gas is introduced for load balancing or storage. Therefore, it is important to consider the specific regulatory requirements and consult with the EPA to ensure accurate reporting of emissions during the salt dome mining process for underground natural gas storage facilities.

question: Subpart W Table W-4 has four sections in the final Federal Register publication.  The first and third sections are both labeled "Leaker Emission Factors Storage Station, Gas Service" and both tables have an entry for "Open-ended Line".
answer: In the final Federal Register publication, both the first and third sections of Table W-4A are labeled 'Leaker Emission Factors Storage Station, Gas Service' and both tables have an entry for 'Open-Ended Line'. The emission factors for the 'Open-Ended Line' in both sections are 17.27 scf/hour/component if surveyed using any of the methods in § 98.234(a)(1) through (6), and 11.07 scf/hour/component if surveyed using Method 21 as specified in § 98.234(a)(7). This information is specific to different types of facilities and components, and the calculation involves various parameters such as the count of emission source types, annual emissions, and the minimum and maximum concentration of CH4 in flash gas from onshore production and onshore natural gas gathering facilities.

question: How should we report a facility that combines onshore petroleum and natural gas production and natural gas storage by injecting natural gas for the purposes of both enhanced oil recoveray and storage?
answer: The facility that combines onshore petroleum and natural gas production and natural gas storage by injecting natural gas for the purposes of both enhanced oil recovery and storage must report the activities and emissions associated with onshore petroleum and natural gas production, onshore natural gas processing, and LNG storage. This includes reporting the injection and recovery of natural gas into and from the underground reservoirs, as well as the emissions from atmospheric tanks, flash gas, and the flow to storage tanks. The facility should also report the emissions from LNG import and export equipment, as well as the minimum and maximum concentration of CH4 in flash gas from onshore production and onshore natural gas gathering and boosting. Additionally, the facility should report the emissions using the default whole gas emission factors for onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities and onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting facilities provided in Table W-1A to Subpart W of Part 98. It is important to adhere to the reporting requirements for onshore petroleum and natural gas production, natural gas storage, and enhanced oil recovery operations to ensure compliance with environmental regulations and to contribute to sustainable and responsible resource management.

truth: What constitutes a facility, how to determine the reporting threshold, and reporting of emissions from collocated and dual purpose equipment is as follows: 1) As a first step the reporter must determine the emissions from all equipment listed in 98.232(c) for onshore petroleum and production.  Per section 98.231(a) only sources listed in 98.232(c) need to be considered for threshold determination for onshore petroleum and natural gas production. 98.238 defines “facility” for the purposes of onshore petroleum and natural gas systems.  Per the requirements of 98.3 each “facility” must submit a GHG report for all source categories at that “facility”.  2) Note that while identifying onshore production emissions sources reporters have to determine whether the source is “on the well pad or associated with a well pad”.  The location of production wells within other facilities is inconsequential to this determination.  Sources on a well pad or associated with a well pad across the entire reporting basin have to be taken into consideration.  If your emissions from onshore petroleum and natural gas production are equal to or greater than 25,000mtCO2e, then onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities report as a separate facility and include all emissions sources listed in 98.232(c).  3) Except for onshore petroleum and natural gas production and natural gas distribution, which have unique facility definitions, all other segments subject to subpart W are considered in the threshold determination for a single facility.  You would also include emissions from other source categories at your facility (e.g., stationary combustion).  If there are emissions sources that are dual purpose then the rule requires this piece of equipment to be reported under the majority use industry segment based on guidance provided in EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1024-14 (pp. 1606-1608).  4) For collocated industry segments, which cannot occur in the case of onshore petroleum and natural gas production and natural gas distribution due to the requirements in 98.231(a), EPA has provided guidance on emissions reporting in EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1024-14.  Based on the information provided, the facility cannot be reported as onshore production and natural gas processing combined (see point 1 above).  For all the other segments, the report should use guidance in points 2-3 above to determine the segment under which the facility should be categorized.

It covers all the necessary activities and emissions associated with onshore petroleum and natural gas production, onshore natural gas processing, and LNG storage, and provides guidance on how to report them in compliance with environmental regulations. The answer is highly relevant and addresses all the important aspects of the question.

question: Are dehydration units that are used to dehydrate natural gas extracted from underground storage included within the definition of underground natural gas storage facility?
answer: The definition of underground natural gas storage facility does not explicitly include dehydration units. However, the specific details provided in the regulations should be carefully reviewed to determine if dehydration units used to dehydrate natural gas extracted from underground storage are included within the definition of underground natural gas storage facility. Additionally, based on the provided tables and formula analysis, it is recommended to refer to the regulatory guidelines or additional documentation for a precise determination of whether dehydration units are included within the definition of underground natural gas storage facility. It is important to note that dehydration units used to dehydrate natural gas extracted from underground storage are typically not considered as part of the definition of an underground natural gas storage facility, as they are usually considered as separate facilities or processes within the natural gas production and processing infrastructure.

answer: Yes, only the equipment listed in Table W-5A (Vapor Recovery Compressor) is required to be reported if it is found to be leaking as defined in the rule for liquefied natural gas storage. It seems that the question may need further clarification or context to provide a more specific answer.

truth: LNG facilities will not be surveying the valves, connectors, and other components that are in Gas Service under 98.233(q).  At an LNG facility, a compressor that recovers vapor, but is designed so that it does not have reportable emissions of methane-containing gas, such as a flooded screw compressor, or one with seals purged with pressurized nitrogen, will not be reported, in accordance with the rule and the EPA’s response in Response to Public Comments, EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1026-7 (see pp. 45-46 in http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part1.pdf).  Vapor recovery compressors use a population emission factor, hence there is no leak detection required.  Reporters have to count the number of vapor recovery compressors and use the population emission factor.
